Chennai oil spill: Tamil Nadu CM O Panneerselvam says fishermen will be compensated for losses Chennai oil spill: Tamil Nadu CM O Panneerselvam says fishermen will be compensated for losses “Clean-up op will complete in 1-2 days;Efforts being taken to safeguard fishermen's livelihood;We're working in close coordination,” said Panneerselvam. By: FE Online | Chennai | Published: February 5, 2017 11:58 AM During his review of the clean-up op of the oil spill on Sunday, the Tamil Nadu CM told media that he will provide compensation to fishermen for their loss. (ANI) 
Tamil Nadu Chief Minister O Panneerselvam visited the Ennore port where there was an oil spill recently after two ships collided with each other. On January 28, a ship M T BW Maple, carrying Isle of Man flag recently collided with another cargo ship leading to oil spill in Eastern coast in the deep sea of the Bay of Bengal after it, outside the Kamarajar harbor in Chennai on Friday. 
During his review of the clean-up op of the oil spill on Sunday, the Tamil Nadu CM told media that he will provide compensation to fishermen for their loss. “Fishes caught from this region found fit for consumption and no impact on marine flora and fauna,” he said. 
“Clean-up op will complete in 1-2 days. Efforts being taken to safeguard fishermen’s livelihood. We’re working in close coordination,” said Panneerselvam. He said that the situation is “extraordinary”. “The Centre and State government are working together,” he exclaimed. He said that more than 5700 people have taken part in clean-up ops for the Chennai Oil Spill. Thousands of people had gathered to clean oil spill near Chennai after the two ships collided. The two vessels MT BW Maple and MT Dawn Kanchipuram, which was carrying 32,813 tonnes of POL, had suffered a rupture which led to oil spill. 
The status report said that, “The representative from the International Tanker Owners Pollution Federation Limited (a specialised international agency on ‘Oil Spill Response’ – arranged by the owner/P&I insurers of MT Dawn Kanchipuram) is already in Chennai.” 
Various organisations had joined hands for the clean-up op, as per the status report, the Coast Guard has been coordinating jointly with personnel from the Chennai Port and Kamarajar Port. The state government, its agencies, Indian Oil Corporation, NGOs, Cadet Trainees from maritime educational institutions and fishermen were working at different places of the shoreline.

Union Minister Nitin Gadkari said that the government has ordered a high-level probe, headed by Director General Shipping, to name the guilty behind the oil spill and the report is likely in a month.
